En la ciudad de Tosagua cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal La Inmaculada, este lugar se lo conoce por ser muy dinámico donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y a la cría de animales, por ser una zona con gran vegetación.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Alba, ella tiene 51 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene seis hijos, todos son mayores de edad, tres de ellos que son solteros  aun viven con ella. Su esposo es panadero.

Tienen una pequeña panadería en su casa en donde fabrican y venden todo tipo de pan. Trabajan  todos los días desde las 5am para tener el delicioso pan para la venta y así satisfacer a sus  clientes que les encanta el pan que ellos elaboran. Además de vender en su casa también su esposo sale con el producto a recorrer por toda la ciudad para vender un poco más ya que les lleva los panes hasta la casa a los clientes.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar más harina, sal, manteca y otros ingredientes para elaborar el mejor pan. Está en el Banco Comunal hace 10 años  y le gusta porque los créditos le ayudan a desenvolverse en su negocio. Sus metas son seguir adelante en su negocio y que su familia goce de buena salud.
texts.en:
In the city of Tosagua the "La Inmaculada" Communal Bank meets every two weeks, this place is known as being very dynamic where the majority of its residents working in farming and animal rearing, it is an area with a lot of vegetation.

In this place we meet Alba, she is 51 years old, married with six children from this union, all are grown up, three of them who are single still live with her. Her husband is a baker.

They have a small bakery at their home where they make and sell all types of bread. They work every day from 5am to have delicious bread to sell and satisfy their customers who like the bread that they make. As well as selling at their home her husband also goes out through the city with their produce to sell a little more and to deliver bread to the homes of their customers.

This loan is going to be used to buy more flour, salt, butter and other ingredients to make the best bread. She has been in the Communal Bank for 10 years and she is happy because it helps them to do well in their business. Her goals are to keep doing well in the business and that her family to enjoy good health.

loans.use: To buy flour, salt, butter and other ingredients to make bread.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy school uniforms.

loans.name: Violeta

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Tosagua cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal La Inmaculada, este lugar se lo conoce por ser muy dinámico donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y a la cría de animales, por ser una zona con gran vegetación.

La señora Violeta es socia fundadora del Banco comunal es la presidenta del banco y le gusta porque los socios de su banco son muy cumplidos y por la seriedad de la institución. Tiene 50 años de edad, hace algún tiempo atrás su esposo falleció y de esa relación tiene  cuatro hijos, tres de ellos ya son mayores de edad y una linda chiquilla de 16 años la cual estudia en colegio, tres de ellos aun viven con ella.

Se dedica al comercio vende aliños y especias, además también vende sobrecamas, carteras, ropa entre otras cosas, tiene un pequeño local en el cual vende un solo dia a la semana ya que los otros días se desplaza a otras ciudades a las diferentes ferias que hay en esos pueblos todas las semanas, los productos los compran en Santo Domingo, se dedica hace varios años a lo que es venta de sabanas y carteras pero lleva dos años con el negocio de los aliños.

Este crédito es para comprar aliños, carteras, sabanas entre otras cosas. Su sueño es que su hija sea una profesional.
texts.en:
The “La Inmaculada” communal bank meets every two weeks in the city of Tosagua, a place known for being very dynamic most of whose residents raise animals and farm because it’s an area with much vegetation.

Violeta is a founding member of the bank and its President.  She likes it because the members of her bank meet their obligations and because of the formality of the institution.  She is 50 years old and has been a widow for quite some time; she has four children, three whom are adults and a lovely, young, 16 year old daughter who is in high school.  Three of the children still live with her.

She is a merchant selling seasonings and spices.  She also sells bedspreads, purses and clothing, among other things.  She has a small locale where she sells just one day a week because the other days she goes to markets in other cities that occur every week.  She buys her merchandise in Santo Domingo.  She has been selling the sheets and purses for several years now but she’s only been selling the seasonings for two years.

This loan is to buy seasonings, purses and sheets, among other things.  Her dream is that her daughter becomes a professional.

loans.use: To buy seasonings, purses, sheets, bedspreads, etc.

loans.name: Sukiasyan (Shisha House)

texts.en: N. has a big Arabian cafe-restaurant “ARABICA” in Yerevan that she started in 2010. She sells Arabian cocktails, coffee, nargiles (hookah pipes) and so on. Now she wants to enlarge her business and to increase her product assortment. She also wants to purchase some nargiles from Syria. N. and her husband are both economists. Their children are very involved in the family business.

loans.use: increase her product variety

loans.name: Gladys Antonia

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Tosagua cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal La Inmaculada, este lugar se lo conoce por ser muy dinámico donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y a la cría de animales, por ser una zona con gran vegetación.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Gladys, ella tiene 45 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene dos hijos, el varón es mayor de edad y una chica de 16 años, ambos estudian en Universidad y colegio. Su esposo trabaja de chofer.

Ella tiene una tienda de viveras de consumo en su casa en la cual vende variedad de productos tales como: arroz, azúcar, aceites, detergentes, entre otros. Trabaja todos los días desde las 6am hasta las 19h00 y a veces hasta más tarde, sus hijos le ayudan en su trabajo, nos cuenta que lleva como diez años en su negocio, los productos los compra en el centro de Tosagua y algunos los recibe en su local.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, detergentes, embutidos y otros productos de primera necesidad. Está en el Banco Comunal hace 4 años y le gusta porque los créditos están cuando lo requieren las socias. Sus metas son seguir trabajando y que sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
In the city of Tosagua, the members of the communal bank "La Inmaculada" (The Blesses Virgin), gather every two weeks.  Tosagua is a place known for being very dynamic.  The majority of the residents make their livings in agriculture and raising animals.  It is an area with a lot of vegetation.

This is where we find Señora Gladys.  She is 45 years old, married and with her husband had two children.  Her son is grown, and her daughter is 16 years old.  Both are in school, at the University and in high school.  Her husband works as a chauffeur.

Señora Gladys has a small grocery store in her home.  She sells a variety of products, such as: rice, sugar, oils and detergents, among other items.  She works every day from 6am until 7pm, and at times even later.  Her children help her in her work.  She tells us that she has been in business for about ten years.  She purchases some of her merchandise in the Tosagua town center, and some is delivered to her business.

This loan will be used to increase the stock in her store.  She is going to purchase rice, sugar, oils, detergents, sausages and other basic products.  Señora Gladys has been with the communal bank for 4 years.  She likes the bank because the loans are available when the members need them.  Her goals are to continue working and for her children become professionals.

loans.use: To purchase rice, sugar, oils, detergents, sausages and other basic products.

loans.name: Virginia Hermelinda

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Tosagua cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal La Inmaculada, este lugar se lo conoce por ser muy dinámico donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y a la cría de animales, por ser una zona con gran vegetación.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Virginia, ella tiene 29 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene una linda niña de tres años. Su esposo es trabajador eventual. Está en el Banco Comunal hace cinco ciclos  y le gusta porque los créditos son rápidos y sin tantos papeleos.

Tiene en sus casa una pequeña panadería en la cual trabaja con la ayuda de su esposo cuando él está desocupado pero cuando él está trabajando  hace todo ella sola, trabaja todos los días desde las 5h00 hasta las 15h00 y en las noches desde las 20h00hasta las 22h00 ya que a esta hora deja todo listo para la mañana siguiente hornear el pan. Lleva varios años que se dedica a esta actividad y esto lo aprendió de su mamá.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar harina, sal, manteca y otros ingredientes para elaborar el pan. Sus metas son seguir adelante en su negocio y que este crezca.
texts.en:
The “La Inmaculada” communal bank meets every two weeks in the city of Tosagua, a place known for being very dynamic most of whose residents raise animals and are farmers because it’s an area with much vegetation.

We met Virginia here.  She’s 29 years old, married and has a lovely, 3 year old, daughter.  Her husband is a temporary worker.  She’s been in the communal bank for five cycles and likes it because the loans are quick without so much paperwork.

She has a small bakery at home that she runs with help from her husband when he’s unoccupied but when he’s working she does all the work by herself.  She works every day from 5am until 3pm and at night from 8pm until 10pm which is when she leaves everything ready for the following day’s bread baking.  She’s been in this occupation for several years; she learned it from her mother.

She will use the loan to buy flour, salt, lard and other bread baking ingredients.  Her goal is to stay in business and that it grows.

loans.use: To buy flour, salt, lard, eggs and other baking ingredients.

loans.name: Mrs. Kuch Tin Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of fifteen people from Prey Phdau Cheung village, Takeo province. They will use their portion of the loan in different ways to improve their families' living conditions. They have selected Mrs. Kuch T. as the village bank president. Mrs. Kuch T. was born in 1979 and is a weaver who makes money by selling silk cloth to support her family. Since her business is getting on well, she wants to expand. To improve her business, Mrs. Kuch T. is seeking a loan to buy more silk for weaving. Her husband, Mr. Chea Em, is a construction worker and a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land where he grows rice for sale to support his family. This couple supports two children: one is a student, while the other is only seven months old.

loans.use: To buy more silk for weaving

loans.name: Rosa Hilda

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Tosagua cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal La Inmaculada, este lugar se lo conoce por ser muy dinámico donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y a la cría de animales, por ser una zona con gran vegetación.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Rosa, ella tiene 35 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene tres hijos de 10,  8 y 5 años de edad,  los dos mayores  estudian en escuela. Su esposo esta en el exterior trabajando. Es socia del Banco Comunal hace 11 años que se desempeña como secretaria del mismo y le gusta porque  los créditos se le han ayudado mucho en su negocio.

Es un ama de casa que también se dedica al comercio, vende ropa de todo tipo y sandalias. También es consultora de belleza y vende productos de Yanbal, Avon y Saysons (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas). Trabaja tres días a la semana, deja sus productos a crédito y cobra cada semana o cada quince de acuerdo a lo que quieran sus clientes. Sus productos los recibe en su casa y lo que es ropa y sandalias las va a comprar a Guayaquil las veces que necesite al mes.

Este crédito es para comprar perfumes, cremas, cosméticos, sandalias y ropa. Sus sueños son tener una boutique.
texts.en:
The “La Inmaculada” communal bank meets every two weeks in the city of Tosagua, a place known for being very dynamic most of whose residents raise animals and farm because it’s an area with much vegetation.

This is where we met Rosa, 35.  She’s married and has three children who are 10, 8 and 5 years of age.  The two oldest are in school.  Her husband is working abroad.  She’s been a member of the communal bank for 11 years and is its Secretary.  She likes it because the loans have helped her business quite a bit.

She is a housewife but also a merchant.  She sells all types of clothes and sandals.  She’s also a beauty consultant and sells Yanbal, Avon and Saison brand products (beauty products, cosmetics, perfumes and women’s accessories).  She works three days a week.  She sells on credit and collects payments weekly or biweekly according to her customers’ wishes.  The beauty products are delivered to her at home but she goes to Guayaquil to buy the clothes and sandals as often as necessary during the month.

She will use this loan to buy perfumes, creams, cosmetics, sandals and clothes.  Her dream is to own a boutique.

loans.use: To buy creams, perfumes, cosmetics, sandals and clothes.

loans.name: Lery Lethy

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Tosagua cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal La Inmaculada, este lugar se lo conoce por ser muy dinámico donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y a la cría de animales, por ser una zona con gran vegetación.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Lery, ella tiene 45 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos, dos mayores de edad y una de 11 años la misma que este año empieza el colegio.  Su esposo es comerciante tiene un puesto en el cual vende legumbres.

Ella tiene una tienda de viveras de consumo en su casa en la cual vende variedad de productos tales como: arroz, azúcar, aceites, detergentes, entre otros. Trabaja todos los días desde las 6am hasta las 21h00 y a veces hasta más tarde, su esposo a veces le ayuda en su tienda, nos cuenta que lleva dos años en su negocio y los productos los compra en Tosagua y algunos  los recibe en su local.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, detergentes, embutidos y otros productos de priM. necesidad. Está en el Banco Comunal hace dos años y le gusta porque con uno de los  créditos empezó su negocio y con los otros ha podido ir poco a poco aumentando sus productos que le permite ganarse la vida y ayudar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar. Su meta es tener una tienda más grande.
texts.en:
The “La Inmaculada” communal bank meets every two weeks in the city of Tosagua, a place known for being very dynamic most of whose residents raise animals and farm because it’s an area with much vegetation.

This is where we met Lery.  She is 45 years old, married and has three children, two adults and an 11 year old girl who will start secondary school this year.  Her husband is a merchant; he has a stand where he sells vegetables.

She has a home-based grocery store where she sells such things as: rice, sugar, oil and detergents, among others.  She works every day from 6am until 7pm and sometimes even later.  Her husband helps out in the store sometimes.  She tells us that she’s been in business two years.  She stocks up in Tosagua and some of her items are delivered to the store.

She will use the loan to better stock the store.  She will buy rice, sugar, oil, detergents, cured meats and other basic need items.

She’s been in the communal bank for two years and likes it because she started her business with one of the loans and with the others has been able to gradually increase her stock items that allow her to earn her livelihood and help her husband with household expenses.  Her goal is to have a larger store.

loans.use: To buy sugar, rice, detergent, oil, cured meats and other basic need items.

loans.name: Mrs. Soeng Thavy Village Bank Group

texts.en: Sixteen people who make up this village bank loan live in Prey Phdau Cheung village in Takeo province. They will use their portion of the loan to improve the lifestyle of their families. They have selected Mrs. Soeng T. as the village bank president. Soeng T. is a weaver who is able to earn some money from selling silk cloth to support her family. Since her business is getting on well, she wants to expand. To improve her business, Mrs. Soeng T. is seeking a loan to buy more silk for weaving. Her husband, Mr. Phyra Brak, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where he grows rice for sale to support his family; he is also a construction worker. This couple supports a yE. old child.

loans.use: To buy more silk for weaving

loans.name: Cecelia

texts.en:
Cecelia is a married woman who lives in San Carlos City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a sari sari (general) store.  Her husband Edcor, who is 40 years old, works as a government utility employee to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities. They have one child who is 8 years old. Cecelia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family.  With the help of her past 15 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Cecelia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 9,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 3,000 thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 16th loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future for her children's education. Cecelia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Ros

texts.en:
Mrs. Ros S. was born in 1969.  She is living in Samraong village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 2.5-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family.  Her husband, Mr. Vanny Chea, is a cattle trader and also a taxi driver. This couple supports two children, who are both students. 

Mrs. Ros S. has a problem because her children must travel to school far away from home. So to improve this condition, she is applying for a loan to add her savings to buy a new motorbike. 

[Her husband is taken the photo with her]

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena P. is from the village of Camul, Tampilisan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 63 years old. Lorena is married and has eight adult-aged children. To make a living, Lorena owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Lorena has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately $18 a month for these activities.

In 2011, Lorena joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorena is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 1st loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Leny

texts.en:

Leny has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $75 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Leny joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Leny is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 2nd loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

Juanita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to add her capital. This loan will be the sixth loan Juanita has taken out from PMPC. Elvira P. is 42 years old. Elvira is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Elvira owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.name: Hourt

texts.en:
Hourt S., 42, resides with her family in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. S. sells snacks and cakes at a local public school, earning an income of USD 10 per day. Her husband is a carpenter, earning an income of USD 5 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 70 on food and USD 45 on the other necessary expenses. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a motorbike for the family use. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the family use

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing general services to local community members. Evangeline is just starting this business.

Mrs. Leak P. and her husband are farmers who own a 3-hectare plot of land where they grow rice to sell to support their family.  He is also a  fisherman. 

It is now time to plant rice in her field and and Mrs. Leak P. needs some money to do this work. To improve production, she is applying for a loan to buy rice seeds, fertilizer, gasoline, and a water pump. 

This couple supports four children, one is employed in garment factory, two are farmers, and one is a duck breeder. She and her family are living in Pongro village in Takeo province. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds, fertilizer, gasoline, and a water pump

loans.name: Haim

texts.en:
Haim P. is 29 years old.  She lives in Siem Reap province. Her husband is 32 years old and is a fisherman who works along a local river. She makes a living by selling the fish that her husband gives her or those that she buys from other fishermen. Haim P. has been running her business for over five years.  She currently earns an average of US$ 4 a day.    

Haim P. is the mother of two children who are both in school.  She is a hard-working woman who never wastes time while engaging in her business activities. As a result of the increasing demands from her clients, Haim P. is applying for a loan so she can purchase more fish to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more fish t o sell

loans.name: Annie

texts.en:
Annie C. is from the village of Linangkayan, Naawan, Misamis Oriental. She is 42 years old. Annie is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Annie owns & operates a business venture in the services sector operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing motorcycle or habal-habal services with her husband as the driver to local community members. Anne is buying and selling used colthing and has been engaged in this business for over 1 year. She earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Annie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Annie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. 

Annie is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the motorcycle service. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Annie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of her motorcycle service

loans.name: Korb

texts.en:
Mrs. Korb V. works as a recycle materials seller and a pig breeder to earn money to support her family.  Her husband, Mr. Sophen Heng, is a fisherman and a farmer who owns a 3-hectare plot of land where he grows rice to sell to support his family. 

In the rice field, the couple has a problem because the land has infertile soil.  To improve their rice production, Mrs. Korb V. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer for their rice farm, and to buy more recycle materials for resale. 

Mrs. Korb V. is a mother of three children, two are students and the youngest one is still only 2 years old. She was born in 1983. She and her family are living in Pongro village in Takeo province. Her husband is pictured in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for rice farm

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth C. is from the village of Linangkayan, Naawan, Misamis Oriental. She is 30 years old. Janeth is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Janeth owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling ready to wear clothing & pillows products in the local community. She also makes and sells sweet potato and banana cues. Janeth has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Janeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Janeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. 

Janeth is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like t-shirts & blouses. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Janeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the  business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like t-shirts & blouses

loans.name: Khuon

texts.en:
Mrs. Khuon K., who lives in Pongro village in TaK. province, was born in 1986. She is a farmer who owns a 3-hectare plot of land where she can grow rice to sell to support her family. The rice field has infertile soil, is far away from the irrigation system, and has a lot of insects, so she needs some money to improve production. Mrs. Khuon K. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline and pesticide. 

Her husband, Mr. Sok Horn, owns a plowing machine to hire out to farmers to earn some money to support his family, and he is a fisherman, too. This couple supports a child who is too small to work or study. Her husband is presented in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticide

loans.name: Elenita

texts.en:
Elenita B., from the village of Kanitoan, Initao, Misamis Oriental, is 32 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Elenita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods and beverages in the local community. Engaged in her business for over two years, she earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Elenita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital, she is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods and snack foods. Elenita plans to use the extra revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods

loans.name: Daya Pertiwi Group

texts.en:
Gusti Ayu S. is a housewife, aged 33, who lives in the village of Tegal Cangkring with her husband and two children. Her daily business is pig-raising near her house, together with her husband who also works as a farmer. 

She also is the leader of "Daya Pertiwi" group which is working together with MUK to fund its pig-raising activities. After having successfully repaid the loan from the last period, Gusti Ayu S. has returned to MUK for her third loan in the amount of Rp. 1.800.000. The loan amount, together with a little additional capital derived from profits from the last period, will be used to buy piglets and pig feed. 

Gusti Ayu S. hopes that if she continues to grow her pig-raising business she will gain even greater financial benefits that can improve the living conditions of her family and of course pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen G., from the village of Tigdok, Tudela, Misamis Occidental.She is 44 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Helen owns and operates a bakery business in the local community. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.


In 2009, Helen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 10000 PHP from PMPC that was used to purchase additional raw ingredients for her bakery, she is requesting her seventh loan of 25000 PHP to expand the business. Helen plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.



About PMPC:



Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Pheng

texts.en: Pheng S. is a 32-year-old married woman who lives in the province of Kompong Cham, which is the best territory for farming. Pheng S. is a married woman who is devoted to her two young children. They attend school and rely on her for their care. Pheng S. owns a farm that she inherited from her grandmother. She uses the land to cultivate seasonal rice crops. Her husband works as a chief carpenter in and around his village. Phen S. bought a plot of land on credit on which to build a house. Presently, her savings are not enough to pay for it. To solve this problem, Pheng S. is requesting a loan from Kiva to add to her savings to pay for this land.

loans.use: To pay for land

loans.name: Korng

texts.en:
Korng S., 46, resides with her family in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for its Pre-Angkorean temples. S. is a silk weaver, earning an income of 2 USD per day. Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of 1.50 USD per day.  Each month, the family has to spend 50 USD on food and 52 USD on other necessary expenses.

S. is requesting a loan of 500 USD to purchase more raw silk to produce silk products for sale. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: buy more raw silk to produce silk products

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan B. is from the village of  Bagong Silang, Iligan City. She is 43 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Susan owns and operates a business buying and selling fruit such as bananas and mangoes. Susan has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Susan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Susan has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital.

Susan is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fruit such as bananas and rambutan to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Susan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional fruit to sell

Gemma has been engaged in her business for 2 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities. Gemma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional pigs to sell. Gemma is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP with which she will purchase additional inventory and use for working capital. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Gemma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. loans.name: Tuon

texts.en:
Mrs. Tuon P. was born in 1970 and is married to Mr. Deal Kos. They live in Svay Sar village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land where she can grow rice to sell to support her family. Her husband is a duck breeder who is able to earn some money by selling duck eggs. Since her husband’s business is getting on well, she wants to expand. Mrs. Tuon P. is, therefore, seeking a loan to buy duck food. With the rest of the loan she is going to buy net to build a duck house. 

She is the mother of six children, four of whom are students, one is a seamstress in a garment factory and the other is a barber. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy duck food

loans.name: Khourn

texts.en:
Khourn M., age 30, resides with her family in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for its Pre-Angkorean temples. Khourn M. is employed at a factory, earning an income of 2 USD per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of 2 USD per day. Each month, the family has to spend 40 USD on food and 60 USD on other necessary expenses.

M. is requesting a loan of 600 USD to purchase a new motorbike for the family to use. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for the family to use

loans.name: Pen

texts.en: Pen S., 40, resides with her family in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. S. sells traditional kites, earning an income of 5 USD per day. Her husband produces wooden furniture, earning an income of 5 USD per day. Each month, the family has to spend 50 USD on food and 70 USD on the other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of 1,000 USD to expand her husband's business. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To expand her husband's business

loans.name: Ratna Sari Group

texts.en:
Ni Putu A. is a 35-year-old woman living in the town of Melaya - Bali. Ni Putu A. is the "Ratna S." group leader, a 15-member group loan offered by MUK. Ni Putu A. is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Ni Putu A. owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. 

Ni Putu A. has been engaged in this business for over 4 years and earns approximately 500,000 IDR a month from these activities. Ni Putu A. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,400,000 IDR from MUK. She is now requesting a new loan of 1,400,000 IDR which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. She has a dream of supporting her children's education from the profit that she get from this business.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita R. is from the village of Brgy. Sto. Domingo West, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 50 years old. Anita is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Anita owns and operates a motorcycle transport service. Anita has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Anita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase tires and other accessories. Anita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Anita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

texts.en:
Alicia is from the village of Tigdok, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 55 years old, married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Alicia runs a general store in the local community. Alicia has been engaged in her business for 2 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities. 

Alicia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Alicia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP with which she will purchase additional inventory and use for working capital. This will be the 14th loan taken out by Alicia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Mr. Kim B. is a villager in Kakaoh village in Takeo province. He was born in 1965. He owns a rickshaw so that he can earn some money to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Long Koem, is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family. Now he wants to breed two cows but his savings are not enough to buy them. So, Mr. Kim B., is applying for a loan to buy two cows for breeding to start a new business. 

He is the father of four children: one is a seamstress in garment factory, one is a laborer and the others are studying in the local public school. His wife is in the photo with him.

loans.use: To buy two cows

loans.name: Purisima

texts.en:
Purisima is a married woman who lives in Toledo City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a car wash/repairs and a general store businesses. Her husband Tadeo, who is 40 years old, works as a construction worker to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have five children who are between 3 and 15 years old. Purisima joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Purisima has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 20,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000 to buy equipment and tools to provide better service to her customers so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Purisima is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org

loans.use: To purchase additional equipment and tools

loans.name: Eak's Group

texts.en:
This group of borrowers consists of four people who live together in Siem Reap province. Eak T., aged 41, has been selected to be the leader of the group. Eak T. is a local fisherman. He doesn’t have a life partner as he has been divorced from his wife for years. Eak T. wakes up every morning, drives his boat toward the middle of the river and fishes. After the fishing is done, he brings his fish to the market and sells to his regular buyers. He is currently earning an average of $3 each day. As fishing is his main source of income, Eak T. is applying for a loan to purchase more nets so that he can accrue more fish. 

The other three members include: 
Mr. M., a fisherman, who is asking for a loan to buy wood to mend his old house.
Mrs. C. is applying for a loan to buy nets to catch more fish.
Mrs. C. will use this loan for sustain her merchandise business.

loans.use: To purchase more nets

loans.name: Khuon

texts.en:
Mrs. Khuon R. is a married woman who was born in 1972. She lives in Prey Chheu Teal village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family. Her husband is a recycled goods seller who also earns some money with which to support his family. Although they both try to work hard, they earn a small income. To improve this condition, Mrs. Khuon R. is asking for a loan to buy two piglets, some chickens and pig food to start a new business breeding animals. 

She is the mother of four children, three of whom are studying at the local public school while the other one is too young to work or study. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy two piglets, some chickens and pig food

loans.name: Cerenia

texts.en:
Cerenia lives in the village of Taguima, Tudela Misamis Occidental. She is 56 years old, married and has one grown child. For the last two years, she has made a living by selling food to people who live in her community. She earns about PHP 4,000 a month from her work.

Cerenia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC and is applying for a new one, for 14,900 PHP, to continue improving and expanding her business. 

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Pach

texts.en:
Mrs. Pach K. is a villager in Srae Boeng village in Takeo province.  She was born in 1961. She and her husband, Mr. Hen Min, are farmers who own a 3-hectare plot of land where they grow rice to sell to support their family.  She also works as a farming laborer. 

In the rice field, Mrs. Pach K. has problems because her field has infertile soil and a lot of insects.  To improve their rice production, she is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide, and to pay for the plowing of the field. 

Mrs. Pach K. is a mother of three children, two are seamstresses in garment factories, and the other is staying at home to look after her child. 

Her husband is present in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer & pesticide, and pay for plowing cost

loans.name: Nget

texts.en: Nget P., 32, is married and lives with her husband and two young children in Takeo province. She makes a living as a factor worker, earning $4 a day. Her husband, 35, Sou Tha, is a wedding chef, and on a typical day earns about $5. Both of their children are in school. Nget P. has decided to increase her income by opening a cafe, and has applied for a loan for $1,000 to make this possible. In the photo, we see her with her husband in their home.

loans.use: To increase her income by opening a cafe

loans.name: Bun

texts.en:
Mrs. Bun C. lives in Krang Touch village in Takeo province.  She was born in 1976.  She is a farmer who owns a 6-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family.   Her husband, Mr. Ech Bun, is a construction worker. Through these activities, they support three children --  two  are attending the local public school, and the other is still only 3 years old. 

In the rice field, Mrs. Bun C. has an obstacle because her field has infertile soil.  To improve her rice production, she is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Sigrid

texts.en:
Sigrid lives in the village of Pan-ay, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 40 years old, married and has three school-aged children. For the last five years, she has made a living by running a general store and earns about PHP 3,000 a month from her work. 

Sigrid joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid two previous loans from PMPC and is applying for a new one, for 14,900 PHP, to buy more items to sell to her customers.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Hum

texts.en: Hum C., 27, is a garment worker in Takeo province, and earns about $3 a day. She is married and has one child who is still living at home. Her husband makes a living by raising poultry and growing rice, and also earns about $3 each day. Hum has applied for a loan for $700 to help her husband expand his business by buying fertilizer and more pigs to raise. We see Hum C. here with her husband in front of their home.

loans.name: Nhoung

texts.en:
Mrs. Nhoung S. M. is 32 years old.  She is married to Mr. Chin Song.  They are living in Si Sla village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land where she cultivates rice to sell to support her family.   Her husband is a duck breeder and a construction worker. 

Mrs. Nhoung S. M. has a problem because her husband’s work place is far away from their home.  To improve this condition, she is requesting a loan to buy a motorcycle for her husband's transportation.  

This couple has three children --  two are enrolled in the local public school and the third is still too small to work or study. Her husband is pictured in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth B. lives in the town of Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 45 years old, married and has three school-aged children. Elizabeth makes a living by running a specialized store where she sells items such as glasses, watches and handbags to people who live in her community. She has been in business for more than 25 years and earns about 7,000 PHP a month from her work.

In 2009, Elizabeth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid three loans from ASKI and is applying for a new one, for 30,000 PHP, to buy more products to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to improve her family's living conditions. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern parts of the country. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and women, and small entrepreneurs.
