loans.name: Cherry Fe

texts.en:
Cherry Fe is from the village of Napurog, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old, married and has two infants. Cherry Fe owns and operates a specialized retail store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Cherry Fe has been engaged in her business for 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from it. 

Cherry Fe joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Cherry Fe is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and use for working capital. This will be the second loan taken out by Cherry Fe from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Sophea's Group

texts.en: This group loan consists of four members who live in Kansaom Khlaeng village in Takeo province. They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their families' standard of living. Mr. Sophea O. is the group leader, selected by the other members. He is a construction worker and a farmer who owns a small piece of land where he grows rice to sell to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Srey Sor Choeun, does housework. This couple supports two children who are both too young to work or study. At present, he has a problem because he does not have enough water. To improve this situation, he is applying for a loan to dig a pool to collect water for use in the dry season.

loans.use: To dig a pool to collect water for use in the dry season

loans.name: Proem

texts.en: Proem C. is 41 years old and lives with his wife and four young children in Battambang province. To earn a living, he has been working as a recycler and is able to make about US $7 every day. His wife stays at home making food and taking care of their children. Proem C. is asking for a loan of US $250 to reinvest in his recycling business.

loans.use: to reinvest in his recycling business

loans.name: Salim

texts.en:
Salim is a married man who owns a house that has no electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food. 

Salim has operated an electronics repair business for the past three years, going from door-to-door repairing electronic sockets. He hopes to establish a wholesale shop in the future. Salim plans to use this KES 30,000 loan to purchase electronic appliances. He decided to work with Yehu because of its simple training.

loans.use: to purchase electronic appliances

loans.name: Evans

texts.en: Evans is 32 years old, married and blessed with two children. To earn a living, he sells green bananas. He has been in the business for five years and has been able to improve his business with his previous loans from Faulu Kenya. Evans hopes to become financially stable in the future. He needs this 30,000 KES loan to buy green bananas.

loans.use: to buy green bananas

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy materials for his business

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en: Jacqueline is a married woman who lives in Toledo City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a motorcycle transport.  Her husband Arcadio, who is 33 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living. They have three children who are between 7 and 11 years old. Jacqueline joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Jacqueline has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 8,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000 uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 13,000 to buy new tools and equipment for her motorcycle transport business so that she can serve more passengers and earn a higher income. Jacqueline is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: To buy new tools to maintain her motorcycle

loans.name: Mrs. Mom Chan Village Bank Group

texts.en: Fourteen people make up this village bank loan based in Prey Kuy village in Takeo province. They will each use their portion of the loan in various ways to improve their families' standard of living. Mrs. Mom C. is the village bank president who has been selected by the other members. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sorn Bak, is a construction worker. They support four children, three of whom are seamstresS. in garment factories while the other is a student. Recently, she has a problem because her house is not comfortable for living. To improve this condition, Mrs. Mom C. is applying for a loan to add to her savings to build a new house.

loans.use: To build a new house

loans.name: Emma Babayran Group

texts.en:
Emma is a 50-year-old woman from the village of Dela Paz Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is the group leader of this three-member group. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if they are delinquent or default.

Emma is married and has four adult-age children. To earn a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector. Specifically, she plants and harvests rice for sale in her local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2007, Emma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services. In turn, she has been better able to engage in business activities and to thereby improve her standard of living. Notably, this would be her seventh loan through PMPC. Most recently, she successfully repaid a prior loan in the amount of 14,000 PHP from PMPC, which was used to purchase additional inventory and for additional working capital. Emma is now requesting another loan, this time in the amount of 14,900 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product line. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To expand adn improve her business by purchasing additional inventory

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
Mohamed is a single man with one child who is still too young for school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for his family.

To earn a living, he operates a fruit-selling business. Specifically, he sells avocados at the market to market dwellers and to his neighbours. Mohamed hopes to own a retail shop in the future.

He is now seeking a loan in the amount of 30,000 KES ($375) to purchase sacks of avocados for re-sale purposes. He decided to join Yehu in order to be able to better engage in business activities.

loans.use: To expand and improve his business by purchasing additional avocados

loans.name: Mrs. Bresh Mabb Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Bresh M. is a village bank president who has been selected by ten people who make up this village bank loan. They each want to improve their families' living standard with their portion of the loan. They are located in Doung Khpos village in Takeo province. 

Mrs. Bresh M. is a door-to-door clothes and mosquito net seller. In this way she can earn some profit with which to support her family. As her business is going well, she wants to expand. She is, therefore, applying for a loan to buy more clothes and mosquito nets to resell. 

Her husband, Mr. Vat Vong, is a farmer who owns a plot of land where he grows rice,  not for sale, but to support his family. They have three children; one is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is a student and the other is 2 years old.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and mosquito nets for resale

loans.name: Y

texts.en: Y T. is a 35-year-old woman who lives in a medium-sized home with family members in Kompong Cham Province. She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. She uses this land to grow different kinds of crops such as cabbages, cucumbers and rice. She sells these crops to buyers every two or three months when the plants mature. Her husband grows these crops with Y T.. They have three single children, all of whom are students at the local school. Y T. will use her loan to clear a field so that she can plant more rice crops.

loans.use: To clear a field for crops

loans.name: Felicidad

texts.en:
Felicidad is a married woman who lives in Toledo City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: making pillows and food vending.  Her husband Federico, who is 58 years old, works as a driver to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have six children who are 12 to 33 years old. Felicidad joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Felicidad has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 11th loan, she is borrowing PHP 16,000 to buy some items for her pillow business so that she can continue to save up for future renovation of their house. Felicidad is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase some items for her pillow-making business

loans.name: Mwita

texts.en:
The man in the photo is Mwita J. M., who is a businessman. More specifically, he runs Royal Vetcare Services to earn a living for his family. He explains that most of his customers are livestock farmers. He has been operating this business for just one year. In addition, he sells farm produce to supplement his family’s income. In the future, he hopes to open a large veterinary clinic.

He is requesting a loan in the amount of 20,000 KES ($250) to buy medicine for animals, syringes, and needles.

loans.use: To expand and improve his business by purchasing animal health care tools and medicines

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok N., 45, is married and lives with her husband in Battambang province. She sells roast beef and dessert in the local market and is able to make a profit of about US $5 every day. Her husband is a construction worker who builds houses. On average, he is able to earn US $4 per day. This couple has seven children; four are in school and two are employed. Sok N. is asking for a loan of US $1200 to finish her construction.

loans.use: to finish construction

loans.name: Mrs. Touch Sokea Village Bank Group

texts.en:
In Dei Kraham village, Takeo province, fourteen people have selected Mrs. T. S. to be a village bank president. All the members of this group loan  will use their portion in various ways to improve their families' standard of living. 

Mrs. T. S. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she grows rice, not to sell, but to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sarom Moav, is a motorcycle taxi driver in Phnom Penh city. Although they try to work hard, they can only earn a small income. Mrs. T. S. would, therefore,  like to ask for a loan to buy some piglets to breed to start a new business. She is the mother of five children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory while the others attend the local public school.

loans.use: To buy piglets for breeding

loans.name: Greta

texts.en:
Greta A. is from the town of Guibang, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 53 years old, married and has 3 adult-aged children. Greta owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling different vegetables in the local community. Greta has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2008, Greta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Greta has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Greta is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Greta from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Oem

texts.en: Oem N. is 61 years old and lives with his wife and one of his children in Battambang province. He and his wife have been recyclers since 2000 and are able to make a profit of about US $7 every day. Oem N. is asking for a loan of US $800 to reinvest in his recycling business.

loans.use: to reinvest in his recycling business

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
Josie S. is from the town of Guibang, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 58 years old, married and has 2 adult-aged children. Josie owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Josie has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2008, Josie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josie has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI, which was used to purchase new items to expand product offering. Josie is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Josie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has no electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Pauline has operated a vegetable stall for the past year, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Pauline faces a major challenge of high transportation costs in her business. She hopes to expand her business in the future. Pauline plans to use this KES 30,000 loan to purchase building materials to finish three rental rooms. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase building materials to finish three rental rooms

loans.name: Mrs. Chhorvorn Saom Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Fourteen people make up this village bank loan in Ta Muong village, Takeo province. They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their families'  standard of living. They have selected Mrs. Chhorvorn S. to be their village bank president. 

Mrs. Chhorvorn S. and her husband, Mr. Sambath Moav, are farmers who own a small piece of land where they grow rice to sell to support their family. He is also a construction worker. They are only able to earn a small income even though they try to work hard. Mrs. Chhorvorn S., therefore, would like to request a loan to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business. She is the mother of two children who are too small to work or study.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie M. is from the town of Guibang, Gamu, Isabela. She is 32 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Rosemarie owns and operates a business making and selling frozen foods to the local community. Rosemarie has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month from it.

In 2011, Rosemarie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosemarie has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rosemarie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Gloria's Group

texts.en:
Gloria D. is from the village of Estrella, San Guillermo, Isabela. She is 41 years old and the group leader of a 13-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Gloria is married and has 4 school-aged children. She owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Gloria has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Gloria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gloria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Gloria is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Gloria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Marie Rose

texts.en: Marie Rose is 25 years old  and has a 3-year-old child. Marie Rose has owned a shop in which she sells vegetables, rice, sugar and cooking oil for 2 years. Marie Rose is requesting a loan in order to buy more vegetables, rice and cooking oil. With the profits she hopes to make, she plans to continue her house construction.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables, rice and cooking oil

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth M. is from the town of Guibang, Gamu, Isabela. She is 42 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Janeth owns and operates a business preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Janeth has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month from it.

In 2007, Janeth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Janeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Janeth is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Janeth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Nob Sopheap Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Sixteen people make up this village bank loan. They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their families' standard of living. They are located in Ta Muong village in Takeo province. All the members have selected Mrs. Nob S. to be a village bank president. 

Mrs. Nob S. and her husband, Mr. Som Somret, are farmers who own a 2-hectare plot of land where they grow rice to sell to support their family. At present her house is not comfortable to live in because it has no electricity. Mrs. Nob S. is, therefore,  requesting a loan to access electricity. She would like to use the rest of the loan to buy some piglets for breeding to start a new business. She is the mother of three children: one is a construction worker, one is a seamstress in a garment factory and the other is a student.

loans.use: To access electricity to use

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma V. is from the town of Guibang, Gamu, Isabela. She is 51 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Elma owns and operates a furniture making business, making and selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Elma has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2007, Elma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. Elma is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Elma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Nzole

texts.en:
Nzole is a married man with five children, three of whom attend school. He owns a house that has no electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

Nzole has operated a business selling charcoal for the past five years, selling at retail and at the market to his neighbors and passersby. He also operates a retail shop which contributes to his other source of income. Nzole faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business. He hopes to expand his business in the future.

Nzole is planning to use this KES 40,000 loan to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Chea's Group

texts.en:
This is a group loan comprised of four borrowers who live in the province of Siem Reap, Cambodia. Chea S. is the head of this group. Mrs. S., 51, catches fish. She usually goes to the middle of the Tunle Sap River where she always fishes. After, she hurries to bring the fish to the market. Her husband owns a boat that he uses to provide a delivery service for a fee. She has five single children and another two who are now married. Chea S. is requesting a loan to purchase nets for her fishing activity. 

The other three borrowers include below: 
Mrs. S., a fish catcher asking for a loan to purchase nets for fishing.
Mrs. K. earns an income by fishing and is asking for a loan to purchase a machine to attach to her existing boat.
Mrs. S. O., fish catcher, is applying for a loan to purchase wood for building her house.

loans.use: To purchase nets

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy materials to repair his house

loans.name: Mrs. Paen Noeurn Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of twenty people who live in Trapeang Roka village in TaK. province. Mrs. Paen N. is the village bank president who has been selected by the other members in the group.   The members will use their portion of the loan in varied ways to improve their famiL. living. 

Mrs. Paen N. is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her famiL..  She has free time outside farming and  wants to start a new business, but she does not have enough money. To achieve this purpose, Mrs. Paen N. is seeking a loan to buy five piglets and pig food to start a new pig breeding business.  Her husband, Mr. Sarun Bach, is a motorcycle taxi driver. This couple supports two children, who are both employed in garment factories.

loans.use: To buy five piglets and pig food

loans.name: Tsogt

texts.en:
Tsogt, 49, is married and lives with his wife and two children in Darhan, the second largest city of Mongolia. They live in their own apartment that they have owned for 24 years. Tsogt's wife and older daughter are employed.

Tsogt began a taxi business in 2004 with his own car. He supports his family with the profit that he makes from the business and his daily net income is 30,000 MNT. He is trying to save some money to buy a new car as his current car is getting out of date. Tsogt is a hardworking and polite person who says, " I am planning to buy a new car since I want to expand my taxi service business more." Tsogt is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 MNT to buy a new car.

loans.use: to buy a new car

loans.name: Salim

texts.en:
Salim is a married man with five children, all of whom attend school. He owns a house that has no electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Salim has operated a business selling charcoal for the past seven years, selling at retail to his neighbors and passersby. Salim faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business. He hopes to expand his business in the future.

Salim plans to use this KES 40,000 loan to purchase sacks of charcoal for sale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en:
Sorn S. is 30 years old and lives in Siem Reap Province. She owns a few rooms that she rents out to tourists who need to relax on their holidays. She also provides a food and soft drink service the whole day. Her husband manages their business. This couple lives with two children who are both teenagers and in school. In addition, they raise chickens to produce eggs and sell the eggs to people who come to buy them in bulk at their house. 

Sorn S. has applied for a $300 loan from Kiva’s partner HKL in order to purchase additional feed and chickens to raise and sell. This will provide her with additional profit, which she will use to better meet her family’s needs.

loans.use: To purchase chickens and feed

loans.name: Ankadignonkonye Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Ankadignonkonyé, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 49 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de warikebougou, préfecture de Barouéli, Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de volailles, de condiments et de céréales.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Ankadignonkonyé sont à leur neuvième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, des poules, des pintades, du haricot et du riz.                                                                         
ATOUMATA SANGARÉ compte acheter une vingtaine de poules et de pintades avec les revendeurs du village et environnants. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement sur place à la maison et au marché de Konobougou, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en: The women in the Ankadignonkonyé group are all married and on average are 49 years old with 4 children. They all live in traditional extended families in the village of Warikebougo, Barouéli prefecture, Ségou Region (fourth administrative region of Mali).  They know one another through ties of community, kinship and friendship. They sell poultry, condiments and grains. The women in the Ankadignonkonyé group are on their ninth solidarity loan, which will be used to buy chickens, guinea fowl, beans and rice. ATOUMATA SANGARE intends to buy around twenty chickens and guinea fowls from retailers in the village and surrounding area. She sells her products daily from her home and at the Konobougou market, in cash and on credit, to a clientele of men and women. She hopes to earn a monthly profit of 20,000 CFA which will be used to pay the loan installments and to make contributions to social ceremonies.  The remainder will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: To buy poultry

loans.name: Mrs. Pach Phally Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Nineteen people from Trapeang Roka village in Takeo province are members of this group loan.  They will use their portion of the loan in varied ways to improve their family living.   The members have selected Mrs. Pach P. to be the group president. 

Mrs. Pach P. is a noodle seller in the local village where she is able to earn some money to support her family.  She is also a pig breeder.  Her husband, Mr. Vannareth Vat, is a farmer who owns a 3-hectare plot of land where he grows rice to sell to support the family. 

In the rice field, this couple has problems because their land has infertile soil, is located far away from an irrigation system, and has a lot of insects.  To improve their rice production, Mrs. Pach P. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticide. 

Mrs. Pach P. is a mother of three children, two of whom are students and the other is still only 2 years old.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticide

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase materials

loans.name: Mwaka

texts.en:
Mwaka is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has no electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mwaka has operated a business selling firewood for the past two years, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Mwaka faces a major challenge of high transportation costs in her business. She hopes to establish a retail shop in the future.

Mwaka is planning to use this KES 30,000 loan to purchase bundles of firewood for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of firewood

loans.name: Aziz

texts.en: Aziz started a restaurant recently in Ramallah city.

loans.use: To expand the business and buy a meat grill

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 27 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Siemana, préfecture de Barouéli, Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de tasses, de galettes, de chaussures et de tubercules.  Les femmes du groupe Benkadi sont à leur sixième prêt solidaire.                                                                                MAMAN T. compte acheter, des ustensiles avec les grossistes du marché de Barouéli hebdomadairement. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement sur place à la maison et au marché, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The women in the Benkadi group are all married, are on average 27 years old with two children and all live in traditional extended families in the village of Siemana, part of the Barouéli prefecture in the Ségou region (fourth administrative region of Mali).

They got acquainted through ties of kinship, neighborhood and friendship. They sell mugs, cakes, shoes, and tubers. The women in the Benkadi group are on their sixth cooperative loan.

Mom T. intends to buy utensils from wholesalers at the weekly market in Barouéli. She makes daily sales locally at home and in the market, for cash and credit to a largely female clientele.

She expects to attain a monthly profit of 10,000 FCFA which will be used to reimburse the loan, pay contributions towards social ceremonies and the rest will be reinvested in her business activity.

loans.use: Buy utensils

loans.name: Mrs. Sokea Nouv  Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of nine people living in Sangkae village in Takeo province. Mrs. Sokea N. is the village bank president, who has been selected by the other members of the group.  The members will use their portion of the loan in varied ways to improve their family living. 

Mrs. Sokea N. is a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land where she grows cucumber and potatoes to sell to earn income to support her family.  Her husband, Mr. Sok Hai Sor, is a driver who earns a small salary to support his family. 

Mrs. Sokea N. faces an obstacle because her house does not have a place for cooking.  To improve this condition,  she is applying for a loan to build a kitchen.   Mrs. Sokea N. is a mother of four children – three of whom work as laborers, and the youngest one is 5 years old.

loans.use: To build a kitchen

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 50 ans, 6 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de warikebougou, préfecture de Barouéli ; Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de bétail, de condiments et de parfums.                                                                                 
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi sont à leur neuvième prêt solidaire.                                                                         AMINATA D. compte acheter quelques de moutons et  chèvres sur pieds dans le village et environnants. Elle effectue ses ventes sur place à la maison et au marché de Konobougou, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 40 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Benkadi Group, all married, are on average 50 years old, have six children and all live in large extended families in the village of Warikebougou, a prefecture of Barouéli, in the region of Ségou (the fourth administrative region in the Republic of Mali).  They know each other through kinship ties, as neighbors and as friends.  They sell livestock, spices and perfume.  The women of the Benkadi Group are on their ninth group loan.

Aminata D. intends to purchase several sheep and goats by foot in the village and its surroundings.  She conducts her sales from her home and at the market of Konobougou, in cash and credit, to a clientele made up of men and women.

She hopes to earn an average monthly profit of 40,000 FCFA which will be used to pay the loan installments, contribute to social ceremonies and the remainder will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: Purchasing livestock

loans.name: Mrs. Aun Ek Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Aun E. is the president of this village bank loan.  She has been selected by the fourteen people from Sangkae village in TaK. province who make up this group.  The members will use their portion of this loan in varied ways to improve their family's standard of living.  

Mrs. Aun E. is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land where she grows rice and vegetables to sell to earn income to support her family.   Her husband, Mr.Thy Chhel, is a motorcycle taxi driver. They support three children who are all studying in the local public school.

Outside farming, Mrs. Aun E. has free time and thus wants to start a new business.  However she does not have money to support this goal.  To achieve her purpose, she is asking for a loan to buy piglets to breed to start a new business.

loans.use: To buy piglets for breeding

loans.name: Octura Group

texts.en:
Jennifer is from the village of Taboo, Jimenez. She is 43 years old and is the group leader of this two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are both collectively responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if they are delinquent or in default.

Jennifer is married and has five adult children. She owns and operates in agricultural sector in  the local community running a livestock in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over seventeen years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Jennifer joined PMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital.

Jennifer is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase new livesctock such as pig to expand her business. This loan will be her eleventh from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To Purchase livestock such as pig

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Danaya, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 47 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Siemana, préfecture de Barouéli ; Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce d’argile blanche et de la couture.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Danaya sont à leur sixième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé par SOUMBA T. pour acheter,                                                                    des sacs d’argile blanche avec les exploitants du village et environnants presque quotidiennement. Elle effectue ses ventes aussi quotidiennement sur place à la maison et au marché, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée exclusivement de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Danaya Group, all married, are on average 47 years old, have four children and live in large extended families in the village of Siemana, a prefecture of Barouéli, in the region of Ségou (fourth administrative region in the Republic of Mali).  They know each other through kinship ties, as neighbors and as friends.  They sell white cosmetic clay and clothing.  The women of the Danaya Group are on their sixth group loan which will be used by Soumba T. to purchase bags of white clay from the village and neighboring operators nearly every day.  She also sells nearly every day from her home and in the market, for cash or credit to a clientele of women.  

She hopes to earn an average monthly profit of 20,000 FCFA which will be used to pay the loan installments, contribute to social ceremonies and the remainder will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: Purchasing white cosmetic clay

loans.name: Map

texts.en: Map I., 50, is a widow who resides in a district of Phnom Penh city in Cambodia. She is a good mother who takes care of two school-aged children, while another one is now married and lives independently. Map I. stays at home to do housework and cooks delicious meals for her children. The family is supported by her daughter, who earns income by providing small loans wI. specific repayment schedules to people who live nearby. Map I.’s son-in-law is a motorcycle taxi (tuk tuk) driver.  His motorbike and is getting old and he often spends his money on repair costs so many times. Map I. really wants to assist him, but she doesn’t enough money to do that.  So she has decided to ask for a loan of $1000, which she will use to buy a new motorcycle for her son-in-law so he can run his a taxi service as usual.

loans.use: To buy motorcycle for son-in-law's taxi business

loans.name: Mehinno

texts.fr: Monsieur  Mehinno est mariée avec  3 enfants  à charge.  Il  est né  en  1957 à  Glidji.  Il habite quartier Gbényédzi  et fait l’élevage  de porc.  Pour  pouvoir nourrir les porcs,  Il s’approvisionne  à vogan.  Il a commencé son activité  en  2006.  Il sollicite un prêt  pour acheter  4 sacs de soja, 2 sacs de manioc, 2 sacs de maïs et 4 porcins.
texts.en: Mr. Mehinno is married and has three children to support.  He was born in 1957 in Glidji. He lives in the Gbényédzi district and raises pigs. To feed his pigs, he stocks up in Vogan. He started this business in 2006. He is requesting a loan to buy 4 sacks of soybeans, 2 sacks of cassava, 2 sacks of corn, and 4 hogs.

loans.use: Buying soybeans, cassava, and corn

loans.name: Nandintsetseg

texts.en:
Nandintsetseg, 29, is married and lives with her husband and two children in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in her father's backyard. Her husband works as a driver for a mining company and her older daughter attends a local primary school. 

Nandintsetseg used to work as a tailor in a clothing factory between 2000 and 2003 in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. In 2004 she moved from Ulaanbaatar to her current home. In 2007 she began manufacturing felt handicrafts. She bought a couple of sewing machines for her business in 2009 with the money she made from her business. Afterward she began making deels, traditional Mongolian long coats, as well as modern clothing by custom order at home. 

She is planning to rent a location to open her workshop and she hopes to hire a couple of tailors to work with her. She is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 MNT to purchase a couple of sewing machines for the workshop that she is going to open soon. She is a hardworking and active person who says, "I wish to operate my own tailoring business where I can produce many kinds of clothes with my own employees in the future."

loans.use: To purchase new sewing machines to grow her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional items to sell

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djekafo, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 43 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Siemana, préfecture de Barouéli ; Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce d’argile blanche, de galette et d’articles divers.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Djekafo sont à leur sixième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter de l’argile blanche, des céréales des articles de boutique.                                                                         
DJENEBA T. compte acheter deux sacs de mil et du beurre de karité pour la préparation des galettes. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement sur place à la maison et au marché, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en: The women in the Djekafo group are all married and on average are 43 years old with 3 children. They all live in traditional extended families in the village of Siemana, Barouéli prefecture, Ségou Region (fourth administrative region of Mali). They know one another through community, kinship and friendship ties. They sell white clay, galettes (a cake similar to a pancake or crepe) and other items. The women in the Djekafo group are on their sixth solidarity loan, which will be used to buy white clay, grains, and boutique items.  Djeneba T. plans to buy shea butter and two bags of millet for making galettes. She sells her products daily from her home and at the market, in cash and on credit to a clientele of men and women. She expects to earn a monthly profit of 20,000F CFA which will be used to pay the loan installments and to make contributions to social ceremonies.  The remainder will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for making galettes.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy essential tools and expand his business
